subject: Re: [junit] Usage of JUnit with VAfJ
msgSnippet: ... From: Jason Rogers ... have ... I m not sure I understand your point. Can you explain? I  use the VAJ toolapi to extract automatically all tests to be run
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: Jason Rogers
> seems that everybody has it's own way of doing things.
> What we do is simply
> put the test classes with the code, in the same package &
> the same project.
> We use different project & packages for special test
> classes (AllTests,
> etc..).

>One of the disadvantages to this is that it makes it a little harder to
have
>that solitary project that will be responsible to run all tests, not
>impossible by any means, it just takes more doing.

I'm not sure I understand your point. Can you explain?
I use the VAJ toolapi to extract automatically all tests to be run (see
below code. Not perfect code, but it's TSTTCPW). They can easily be packaged
in another JAR if needed (with ant for example).

Workspace w = ToolEnv.connectToWorkspace();
BuilderFactory factory = w.createBuilderFactory();
Type allTestsClass = w.loadedTypeNamed("bla.bla.AllTests");
TypeBuilder classBuilder = factory.createTypeBuilder(allTestsClass);
MethodBuilder methodBuilder = factory.createMethodBuilder("");
StringBuffer buffer = new StringBuffer();
buffer.append("static public TestSuite suite() { \n"); buffer.append("
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(\"AllTests for Unit Tests\"); \n");
Enumeration e = (new AllTestSuiteBuilder()).collectTests();
while (e.hasMoreElements()) {
buffer.append("\tsuite.addTestSuite("); buffer.append(e.nextElement());
buffer.append(".class);\n");
}
buffer.append(" return suite;\n }\n");
methodBuilder.setSource(buffer.toString());
classBuilder.addMethodBuilder(methodBuilder); classBuilder.save();
allTestsClass.createVersion(null,true);

collectTests() will find every TestCase subclass in the workspace. I have a
ant script that loads the latest release stuff before running this.

Those running the tests still need the code to be tested anyway. One other
point for this way of having tests in the same package/project that I didn't
mention is that it's very easy to keep versions in sync (tests & code). If
you have two projects, you can end up runnning old tests on newer classes,
etc..

> [...], it's also pretty easy to manipulate them when exporting.
> Why hide the tests? I'm proud of them! :) And I want them
> to be seen right
> aside the class they test, so it gives a visual clue that
> they need to
> follow the evolution of the class. Anyway.... :)
>A moot point from my perspective, but your mileage probably varies.

Indeed, it is a moot point :)

mathieu
